explanation:
For a correct MISRA C analysis of OS_initfs for out-of-bounds use of <string.h> functions you must inspect any code that touches the pointer parameters (address, devname, volname) or that computes sizes/offsets used when copying/moving memory or strings. The minimal additional symbols required are:

- OS_FileSys_Initialize: the direct callee; you must inspect its body to see whether it calls any string.h functions (memcpy, strcpy, strncpy, strlen, etc.) on the passed-in pointers or on buffers derived from those pointers.
- OS_FileSysFormatVolume_Impl: filesystem formatting is the most likely place to copy or write data into the memory region pointed to by address and to handle volname/devname; inspect for memcpy/strcpy/strncpy/strlen and bounds checks against blocksize/numblocks.
- OS_FileSysStartVolume_Impl: starting/mounting a volume may read or copy names and metadata; check for string operations that use devname/volname or internal buffers.
- OS_FileSysStopVolume_Impl: stopping/tearing down a volume may manipulate names or metadata strings; include to be thorough.
- OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken, OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew: these object-id utilities often handle name/token strings (e.g. copying or comparing devname/volname into object tables) and could contain string.h usage that affects safety of devname/volname handling.
- OS_printf: formatting/logging calls can call into formatting/string routines; include to ensure no buffered formatting of user strings writes beyond local buffers (e.g. snprintf misuse). Even if unlikely, it must be inspected when tracing string usage.
- osal_blockcount_t: the numeric type of numblocks is required to reason about size calculations (block count × blocksize) performed by filesystem code; integer width/overflow behaviour affects whether computed copy sizes overflow and lead to out-of-bounds accesses.
- OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE, OS_ERR_NO_FREE_IDS, OS_FS_ERR_DEVICE_NOT_FREE: the error codes used by OS_initfs determine control flow (whether the historic mapping to OS_FS_ERR_DEVICE_NOT_FREE occurs). Knowing these values is necessary to determine which code paths in the callee(s) are exercised and therefore which string operations need to be checked.
- OS_MAX_API_NAME: (representative example of project name/size limits) many OS filesystem/object functions use compile-time maximum name/ path constants when copying or truncating devname/volname; you must inspect those constants (e.g. OS_MAX_API_NAME or other OS_MAX_* name/path limits referenced by the FS code) to verify proper bounds checks were applied before any string.h calls.

Note: if the filesystem implementation or object utilities use additional project-specific size macros or helper functions (e.g. OS_MAX_PATH_LEN, FS label size constants, internal buffer declarations, or utility wrappers around string.h), include those exact symbols as well. The core point is to obtain the implementations and any size-limit definitions used by the FS code so you can check every call to memcpy/strcpy/strncpy/strncat/strlen/etc. that touches the pointers passed into OS_initfs.
